abstracts.cdata!:
The audit gives mixed results in rating
            the three operations, concurring, or not with the
            Implementation Completion (ICR) reports' ratings, as
            follows. It downgrades the Financial Sector and Business
            Environment (FSBEP) Project outcome to unsatisfactory, its
            sustainability to unlikely, institutional development
            impacts to negligible, including both Bank and Borrower
            performances to unsatisfactory; similarly, the Private
            Sector Development Adjustment Credit (PSDAC) is downgraded
            to moderately satisfactory outcomes, unlikely
            sustainability, modest institutional development impacts,
            satisfactory Bank performance, although concurs with a
            satisfactory Borrower performance; and, ratings on the
            Financial and Private Sector Institutional Development
            (FPSIDP) are also downgraded to unsatisfactory project
            outcomes, unlikely sustainability, and negligible
            institutional development impacts, yet, concurs with
            satisfactory performances by the Bank and Borrower. Some of
            the main lessons from these projects suggest that: The
            ethnic divide, distrust, and governance problems, are the
            key constraints to improving the environment for private
            sector development (PSD), and fostering sustainable growth
            in Guyana. At the project level, all future Bank operations,
            including their components and processes (e.g. consultations
            on project design, hiring of consultants, procurement,
            selection of trainees, choice of regulatory options, etc.),
            should address the way to at least, avoid deepening
            distrust, and if possible, serve to build trust across the
            racial divide. Transparency should be the key watchword for
            both the Government, and donors. In addition, more
            diagnostic work on incentives, institutions, and social
            capital is needed, with a view to identifying strategies,
            and tactics for rationalizing incentives, building
            sustainable institutions, and fostering social capital.
            Understanding the political economy is essential to project
            choice, and design.
